text: We actually ended up keeping
the vast majority of the employees there.
The current water utility employees…?
Yes. And that was the first

cognitive bias I decided I 
had to get rid of in my mind.

I had assumed that the employee force
there would not have the capability

to transform this into 
a progressive institution.
Astoundingly, with the right leadership,

they became
a significant competitive advantage.
And why do I say that?

Luckily, our management team—the one
we put in and the human resource

group put in—decided very early on that
they were going to work

pretty much with the whole team
that was already there.

And as they studied the business,
they realized that these individuals,

who’d been incredible,
had tremendous reach into the network
of barangays and local government
units in our zone of distribution.

They had built up a lot of 
trust, a lot of goodwill.

And obviously, they were an important
group in that community.

What happened was that 
the capital needed to keep

the investment going was not forthcoming
in the way that it should be,

and the planning was really not
where it should be as well.

And so they were doing the best
that they could with very, very
limited resources.
We realized that.

We also understood
that the whole performance structure,

payment metrics
and sense of pride were also quite low.

They were constantly blamed
for the lack of water.
They felt a little bit
depressed and unmotivated.
But at the same time, they really knew

the communities
and they really knew the business.

So what we brought in
was capital, a sense of

planning, a massive commitment
to reinvest in the zone—it

had massive underinvestment
for a long time—and

really build up a sense of pride
in the employee force.

Actually, there are so many funny
anecdotes about—after taking over, about

a couple of weeks later,
we had our first board meeting,
and we asked the team, you know,

“How are things going?” And they said,
“Well, our call center…has spiked

up, and we’ve never received
so many complaints in our lives.

It’s by a factor of 20, 30.”
And so we were all aghast at the board.

We said, “But,
you know, we’re supposed to be

the ones supposed to be fixing this.”
So they said, “No,

they called up because they realized
now somebody would listen to them.
It wasn’t because they were complaining.

It was because they now said, ‘You
know what, there’s now an institution

that we can actually have a dialogue with
and say we have needs.’” So

there were so many kind of
interesting learnings as we progressed.
Anyway, it started.

And they became—the workforce became—a
massively important component.

And…I remember thinking at the time,
you know,

I should never have
these cognitive biases again.

And I would say maybe 80 percent to 90
percent of the success of the company

really came from that employee workforce
that had originally been there.

They just didn’t
get the support that they needed

and were not organized in a way that was
conducive to a progressive company.

So fast-forward:
the company’s done very well.
We brought

down I guess non-revenue
water from a large amount—I

think it was over 60 percent, down
to 11 percent, which is a global standard.

We gave investors
a good return for their investment
and the communities that received water

got the price at a fraction of the price
that they were getting.
So it was really a win-win all around.
